description: Afrofuturistic illustration, futuristic woman
Rihanna, as an otherworldly warrior queen, in the September issue of W magazine.
credit: Steven Klein; styled by Edward Enninful

description: Solange Knowles on “Saturday Night Live” in November, flaunting a sundial-size headdress of crystals and tight-woven braids.
“Syzygy,” by the artist Lina Iris Viktor, who paints queenly self-portraits with a futuristic edge.
Erykah Badu’s music and aesthetic embody afrofuturism to the core
Badu is known for her quirky signature style along with her piercing vocals and experimental sound.
From Givenchy’s spring 2014 ready-to-wear collection. Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy was among the first designers to integrate Afrofuturist imagery into his runway shows
Jerome LaMaar, the owner of the South Bronx boutique 9J, in fur-rimmed virtual-reality goggles.
credit: Deidre Schoo for The New York Times

description: n/a

Andre 3000 performs at Lollapalooza in 2014

Afrofuturism has taken on a new public face through a new generation of recording artists — Erykah Badu, Missy Elliott and Janelle Monáe
title: Missy Elliott - The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly) [Official Music Video]

description: A bit of afrofuturism from Janelle Monae’s album

description: The best scenes from the 2018 Black Panther Movie (which brought Afrofuturism to Hollywood/the mainstream)
title: Black Panther (2018) Best Scenes

description: An Afrofuturistic dystopian film
title: Pumzi

description: The first UFO Mothership P-Funk landing, live, direct and in concert. De-boarding this P-Funk-ship enterprise are many drooling clones, legendary funk aliens and their unscrupulous, schizophrenic, ingenious leader...George 'Star Child' Clinton.
title: The Parliament Funkadelic - Mothership

description: WHEN THEY LED A POST-APOCALYPTIC ESCAPE TO THE PYRAMIDS
title: Outkast - Elevators (Me & You)

description: WHEN THEY PAID HOMAGE TO THE PLUTONIA, A FUTURISTIC CITY
title: Outkast - Prototype

description: In this inaugural episode of BK3K we find 2 sisters living in Brooklyn 'sometime in the future'. We soon learn that a basic human need, namely the sun, comes at a premium.
title: They Charge for the Sun

description: The Twi language of Ghanaian word, 'sankofa' meaning 'to return, to seek, to take' is applied in his emotionally tolling, yet thrilling film. Sankofa follows a narcissistic supermodel who is sucked back in time to a West Indies plantation as a slave,
title: Sankofa

description: Afronauts is both a journey back in time and a gaze into the future. It tells the hidden story of Zambian citizens who tried to beat the United States to the moon.
title: Afronauts

0.title: My AfroComicCon 2019 Keynote Address: AfroFuturism + the Climate Emergency
0.author: Aya de Leon
0.description: An address of afrofuturism and the world’s environmental crisis

0.title: Parable of the Sower
0.author: Octavia E. Butler
0.description: Octavia Butler's Parable of the Sower is a stunner. It's a terrifying vision of a dismal future brought on by the willful ignorance, racism and greed of human beings, and an eerily dangerous parallel to our present path.

0.title: Afrofuturism: The World of Black Sci-Fi and Fantasy Culture
0.author: Ytasha Womack
0.description: Comprising elements of the avant-garde, science fiction, cutting-edge hip-hop, black comix, and graphic novels, Afrofuturism spans both underground and mainstream pop culture

0.title: Black Futures Matter: Redefining Afrofuturism
0.author: Melanie McCoy
0.description: Furthermore, the uniqueness of Afrofuturism is that the definition is dependent upon the interest of the Afrofuturist. What does that mean?

0.title: Tracing OutKast’s obsession with space
0.author: Lexi Manatakis
0.description: Space is the Place: we look at the ATLiens’ cosmic narratives following André 3000’s appearance in High Life

0.title: The Comet
0.author: W.E.B. Du Bois
0.description: “The Comet” is a science fiction short story first published in 1920 as the final chapter of his autobiographical collection of poems and essays Darkwater: Voices from Within the Veil.

0.title: Flame Wars: Black to the Future
0.author: Mark Dery
0.description: This is the work where the term Afrofuturism was initially coined in the 1990s

0.title: Dark Matter: A Century of Speculative Fiction from the African Diaspora
0.author: Shiree R. Thomas
0.description: This anthology contains work from some of the best and brightest African-American writers of our time

0.title: Dhalgren
0.author: Samuel R. Delaney
0.description: A mysterious disaster has stricken the midwestern American city of Bellona, and its aftereffects are disturbing

0.title: Binti
0.author: Nnedi Okorafor
0.description: At 96 pages, this novella is a short read that packs a powerful punch, and is a natural addition to the Afrofuturism canon

0.title: The Intuitionist
0.author: Colson Whitehead
0.description: The Intuitionist is a unique novel about integration and racial progress in a world of elevators and their inspectors
